Title: Cantor set in base 3.
Content:
I'm trying to prove the cantor set $C$ is equivalent to the set of all numbers with ternary expansion of $2$'s and $0$'s. That is: Let $A_0=[0,1]$. $A_n$ is defined to equal $A_{n-1}$ with it's middle third removed. let $C= igcap_{n\in\mathbb{N}} A_n$.
 Prove $C =\{x=0.a_1a_2a_3...| a_n\in\{0,2\} 	ext{ for all }n\in\mathbb{N} \} $ where the decimal expansion is in base $3$. Let $x=0.a_1a_2a_3...$ $\space$ be a ternary expansion of $x$ My strategy is this: Prove that $a_n=1 \iff x
otin A_n$ (a) Proceed by induction on $n$.  For $n=1$ we have: $a_1 = 1 \iff  rac{1}{3} \le  x <  rac{2}{3} \iff x 
otin A_1$ Assume it's true for $n$ that is:$\space a_n = 1 \iff x 
otin A_n$. For $n+1$ we have: $a_{n+1}=1 \iff 	ext{there's some integer $m$ such that:}  rac{1}{3} \le 3^{n}x - m  <  rac{2}{3} $ Furthermore $m = a_1a_2a_3...a_{n}$ (in base 3 digit expansion). Here i got stuck.
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $F_1 = [0, rac{1}{3}] \cup [ rac{2}{3},1]$ $F_2 = [0, rac{1}{3^2}] \cup [ rac{2}{3^2}, rac{3}{3^2}] \cup [ rac{6}{3^2}, rac{7}{3^2}] \cup [ rac{8}{3^2},1]$ and so on.
The Cantor set is then $C= igcap^{\infty}_{k=1} F_k$. Each $x \in C$ can be written in the form $ x =  rac{a_0}{3} +  rac{a_1}{3^2} +  rac{a_2}{3^3} + ...+  rac{a_n}{3^{n+1}}+ ...$ By Construction, if $x\in F_k$ and $0 \leq j < k$, then $3^jx=a+y$ where $a \in \mathbb{N} \cup \{0\}$ (*) and $y \in F_{k-j}$. Noting this pattern suppose $x\in C$ therefore $x \in F_k$ for all $k \in \mathbb{N}$. Now assume that for some $m\in \mathbb{N}$  we have $a_m = 1$ Then we have $3^mx=a+ rac{1}{3}+ rac{a_{m+1}}{3^2}+ rac{a_{m+2}}{3^3}+...\ \ \ \Leftrightarrow$  $ \ \ \ \ y=3^mx-a 
otin F_1 \Leftrightarrow x 
otin F_{m+1} \Leftrightarrow x 
otin C$ contradiction. To see the pattern more clearly, consider $F_3$, $F_3= [0, rac{1}{27}] \cup [ rac{2}{27}, rac{3}{27}] \cup [ rac{6}{27}, rac{7}{27}]\cup [ rac{8}{27}, rac{9}{27}]\cup [ rac{18}{27}, rac{19}{27}]\cup [ rac{20}{27}, rac{21}{27}] \cup [ rac{24}{27}, rac{25}{27}] \cup [ rac{26}{27},1]$ Define the "multiplication" of an interval by an scalar, naturally by multiplying the endpoints by that scalar, for example $3F_2=  [0, rac{3}{9}] \cup [ rac{6}{9},1] \cup  [ rac{18}{9}, rac{21}{9}] \cup [ rac{24}{9},3]=[0, rac{1}{3}] \cup [ rac{2}{3},1] \cup  [2, rac{7}{3}] \cup [ rac{8}{3},3]$ This multiplication is important, since it gives us 2 copies of $F_1$, (the 2nd copy is a translation of $F_1$ by an integer, look at (*) ) More generally, $3^jF_k$ gives us $2^j$ copies of $F_{k-j}$ let $x \in F_3$ For $j=0 \ \ \ $, the statement is clear, i.e. $3^0x \in F_{3-0} \Rightarrow x \in F_3$ Trivial ! For $j=1 \ \ \ $Obviously $3^1x \in 3F_3$, i.e. $3^1x$ lies in a translated (by a number $a \in \mathbb{N} \cup \{0\}$) copy of $F_{3-1}=F_2$ Therefore $3x=a+y$ where a is the natural number of translation, and $y\in F_2$ For $j=2 \ \ \ $ Similarly $3^2x \in 3^2F_3 \Rightarrow 3^2x $ lies in a translated copy of $F_{3-2}=F_1$
